bibl.title: Letter from Mark Sullivan to Jefferson Randolph Kean, January 4, 1926

div1.p: Sullivan thanks Kean for all the corrections he supplied for his book on the recent history (1900-1925) of the United States, especially with his chapter on William Crawford Gorgas. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Mark Sullivan to Jefferson Randolph Kean, January 4, 1926
div1.opener:
MARK SULLIVAN
1701 H Street,
Washington, D.C.,
January 4, 1926.
My dear Colonel Kean:
div1.p:
I ought long ago to have acknowledged your friendly
kindness in taking so much trouble, but the fact is that between
doing my daily work, and hurrying back and forth between here and
New York, I have neglected my mail in such a way as to cause me
to feel I owe an apology to a great many people.

Your letter and the enclosures came just after the
final proofs had been read. Happily, though, nearly all the
points you made had already been caught and corrected. We showed
the proofs of that chapter to some twelve or fifteen persons, and
among them they supplied us with practically all the corrections
mentioned in your own letter and memorandum. The chapter as it
appears in the book will be very different from the original proof
which you saw.

You are quite right about the source of most of the
material. As I stated in a footnote, I started with the book written
by Mrs. Gorgas and Hendrick; but through the device of showing the
proof to a large number of people, I have been able to catch all the
changes.

As to the amount of credit due General Wood, I was
fortunate enough in this respect also to be set right by a number
of persons who read the proof, and also by allusions to General
Wood's part, which I found in various books, such as Harvey Cushing's
“Life of Dr. Osler”, and others.

All in all, I think that substantially all the points
made in your memorandum have already been changed in the proof. I
am keeping your memorandum, as well as the one from General Wood
and the one from Colonel Dorey. When the matter of a second edition
of the history comes up, if there are still any changes that need
to be made, I will have your material.

I may add that I have been very much impressed by
finding the abundant testimony of contemporaries to the effect
that a considerable measure of credit was due General Wood. The
fact that Colonel Gorgas' superior happened to be a medical man
made a great deal of difference. It is possible that a non-medical
Governor-General of Cuba might have given Gorgas the same support
MARK SULLIVAN
-2-
that General Wood did. It is possible, I say; but Colonel Gorgas'
experience with a different sort of superior at Panama teaches us what
might have happened - or rather, what might have failed to happen -
at Havana.

I am indebted to you for your trouble. I hope you will
look on the trouble you have taken as a contribution to accuracy of
history.

From your point of view, and from the point of view of
getting the record straight and keeping it straight, it occurs to me
it might be wise and practicable for you to get your corrections of
the Gorgas book together in a collection and deposit them with some
organization where they will be sure to come to the attention of
future historians. There is such an institution - it is one of the
Carnegia endowments, in the Woodward Building here in Washington.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, Mark Sullivan Colonel Jefferson R. Kean.
